    Big operators #

    In this file we define products and sums indexed by finite sets (specifically, Finset).

    Notation #

    We introduce the following notation, localized in BigOperators. To enable the notation, use open BigOperators.

    Let s be a Finset α, and f : α → β a function.

    • ∏ x in s, f x is notation for Finset.prod s f (assuming β is a CommMonoid)
    • ∑ x in s, f x is notation for Finset.sum s f (assuming β is an AddCommMonoid)
    • ∏ x, f x is notation for Finset.prod Finset.univ f (assuming α is a Fintype and β is a CommMonoid)
    • ∑ x, f x is notation for Finset.sum Finset.univ f (assuming α is a Fintype and β is an AddCommMonoid)

    Implementation Notes #

    The first arguments in all definitions and lemmas is the codomain of the function of the big operator. This is necessary for the heuristic in @[to_additive]. See the documentation of to_additive.attr for more information.

    source
    def Finset.sum {β : Type u} {α : Type v} [AddCommMonoid β] (s : Finset α) (f : α → β) :
    β

    ∑ x in s, f x is the sum of f x as x ranges over the elements of the finite set s.

    Equations
    • Finset.sum s f = Multiset.sum (Multiset.map f s.val)
    Instances For
      source
      def Finset.prod {β : Type u} {α : Type v} [CommMonoid β] (s : Finset α) (f : α → β) :
      β

      ∏ x in s, f x is the product of f x as x ranges over the elements of the finite set s.

      Equations
      • Finset.prod s f = Multiset.prod (Multiset.map f s.val)
      Instances For
        source
        @[simp]
        theorem Finset.sum_mk {β : Type u} {α : Type v} [AddCommMonoid β] (s : Multiset α) (hs : Multiset.Nodup s) (f : α → β) :
        Finset.sum { val := s, nodup := hs } f = Multiset.sum (Multiset.map f s)
        source
        @[simp]
        theorem Finset.prod_mk {β : Type u} {α : Type v} [CommMonoid β] (s : Multiset α) (hs : Multiset.Nodup s) (f : α → β) :
        Finset.prod { val := s, nodup := hs } f = Multiset.prod (Multiset.map f s)
        source
        @[simp]
        theorem Finset.sum_val {α : Type v} [AddCommMonoid α] (s : Finset α) :
        Multiset.sum s.val = Finset.sum s id
        source
        @[simp]
        theorem Finset.prod_val {α : Type v} [CommMonoid α] (s : Finset α) :
        Multiset.prod s.val = Finset.prod s id
        source

                    The difference with Finset.sum_nbij is that the bijection is allowed to use membership of the domain of the sum, rather than being a non-dependent function.

                    theorem Finset.sum_univ_pi {ι : Type u_1} {β : Type u} [AddCommMonoid β] [DecidableEq ι] [Fintype ι] {κ : ι → Type u_2} (t : (i : ι) → Finset (κ i)) (f : ((i : ι) → i ∈ Finset.univ → κ i) → β) :
                    (Finset.sum (Finset.pi Finset.univ t) fun (x : (a : ι) → a ∈ Finset.univ → κ a) => f x) = Finset.sum (Fintype.piFinset t) fun (x : (a : ι) → κ a) => f fun (a : ι) (x_1 : a ∈ Finset.univ) => x a

                    Taking a sum over univ.pi t is the same as taking the sum over Fintype.piFinset t. univ.pi t and Fintype.piFinset t are essentially the same Finset, but differ in the type of their element, univ.pi t is a Finset (Π a ∈ univ, t a) and Fintype.piFinset t is a Finset (Π a, t a).

                        theorem Finset.sum_subtype_eq_sum_filter {β : Type u} {α : Type v} {s : Finset α} [AddCommMonoid β] (f : α → β) {p : α → Prop} [DecidablePred p] :
                        (Finset.sum (Finset.subtype p s) fun (x : Subtype p) => f ↑x) = Finset.sum (Finset.filter p s) fun (x : α) => f x

                          theorem Finset.sum_indicator_subset_of_eq_zero {ι : Type u_1} {β : Type u} {α : Type v} [AddCommMonoid β] [Zero α] (f : ι → α) (g : ι → α → β) {s : Finset ι} {t : Finset ι} (h : s ⊆ t) (hg : ∀ (a : ι), g a 0 = 0) :
                          (Finset.sum t fun (i : ι) => g i (Set.indicator (↑s) f i)) = Finset.sum s fun (i : ι) => g i (f i)

                          Consider a sum of g i (f i) over a finset. Suppose g is a function such as n ↦ (n • ·), which maps a second argument of 0 to 0 (or a weighted sum of f i * h i or f i • h i, where f gives the weights that are multiplied by some other function h). Then if f is replaced by the corresponding indicator function, the finset may be replaced by a possibly larger finset without changing the value of the sum.

                                  Deprecated lemmas #

                                  Those lemmas were deprecated on the 2023/12/23.

                                  source
                                  @[deprecated Fintype.prod_equiv]
                                  theorem Equiv.prod_comp' {ι : Type u_2} {κ : Type u_3} {α : Type u_4} [Fintype ι] [Fintype κ] [CommMonoid α] (e : ι ≃ κ) (f : ι → α) (g : κ → α) (h : ∀ (x : ι), f x = g (e x)) :
                                  (Finset.prod Finset.univ fun (x : ι) => f x) = Finset.prod Finset.univ fun (x : κ) => g x

                                  Alias of Fintype.prod_equiv.

                                  Fintype.prod_equiv is a specialization of Finset.prod_bij that automatically fills in most arguments.

                                  See Equiv.prod_comp for a version without h.
